body.p: If you see that some of the CSS properties are not applied, then check the merged map file structure.
This is found besides the PDF file in the out/pdf-css directory, and has the file extension .merged.xml.

Open this file in oXygen, pretty print it (optional, will add white-spaces but makes the structure easier to read) and examine the XML structure. Check that the CSS selector is written correctly. If you cannot solve the problem, then you may try to inspect how the applied styles are applied.

section.title: Inspect the applied styles using the Chrome browser

ol.li: Open the the file ending in .merged.xml file in Chrome.
Click on the element you want to style.
Activate the Chrome Developer Tools by using the Dotted Menu More Tools Developer Tools , or press CTRL+SHIFT+I
Activate the Rendering pane by using the Dotted Menu of Developer Toos More Tools Rendering :

section.note: This allows you to debug styling of elements, table of contents and index, but not the styles of the page margin boxes (headers, footers) or page breaks.
When inspecting styles in the Elements Styles you can click on links to open the CSS files. Editing the styles results in a live preview in the browser.

section.title: Inspect the applied styles using the oXygen XML Editor/Author

ol.li: Open the file ending in .merged.xml file in Oxygen XML Author (Editor)
From the Styles toolbar, choose the + Print Ready entry. This will activate the CSS selectors enclosed in @media print {..}.
Click on the element you want to style. Use the Inspect Styles action from the Contextual Menu. A specialized view will show the buit-in CSS rules.

section.note: This allows you to debug styling of elements, but not of the page margin boxes (headers, footers) or page breaks.

section.title: Other techniques
section.p: These are other techniques you may find useful:

ul.li: Add background and borders properties to the specific CSS rule. If they do not appear in the output then there is a problem with the rule selector and
Try to use the !important notation to the property that is not applied, or make the selector more specific. (You can add more parent selectors)
